_prev_prog_3.Description:
Rich Products Corporation - Waycross Facility's ammonia refrigeration system contains equipment to minimize the potentail of an ammonia release.  The Facility has in place the following for the ammonia refrigeration system:  preventative maintenance procedures, automatic alarm systems, ammonia detectors and ventilation, process safety information tracking logs, periodic leak and pressure testing, periodic visual inspections, control valves, refrigeration hand service valves for manual operation, solenoid valves, pressure relief valves, computer generated work orders for maintenance activities, and hot work permits.

The Facility's administrative procedures are as follows:  periodic training for Associates, compliance audits, pre-startup safety checks, process hazard analysis to address what-if scenarios and the measures taken to mitigate a release, pre-qualifying contractor performing work on the ammonia refrigeration system, and management of change procedures.

Compressors have the following safeguards:  pressure and temperature gauges on suction and discharge piping, high and low temperature alarms and shutdown, high and low pressure alarms and shutdown, high and low oil level alarms and shutdown, high and low oil temperature alarms and shutdown, high and low oil pressure alarms and shutdown, and pressure relief valves.

The pressure vessels (e.g., high pressure receiver) have the following safeguards:  dual pressure relief valves, high and low level alarms and shutdown, continuous level controller, and liquid level sight glasses.

Evaporative condensers have the following safeguards:  dual pressure relief valves, liquid level indicator, water pump startup and shutdown, and high pressure over-ride.

Evaporators have the following safeguards:  high and low level alarms and shutdown, temperature controls, liquid level alarm and shutdown, liquid level gauge, high and low pressure alarms and shutdown, emergency stop switch, and pressure and temperature gauges on suction and discharge piping.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Rich Products Corporation - Waycross Facility produces pizza products which are frozen for shipment by using an ammonia refrigeration system (system).  The system contains approximately 15,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia which is liquified under pressure.
  
Rich Products Corporation - Waycross Facility endeavors to eliminate accidents and health hazards to Associates, customers, and the community by having procedures to provide Associates educational training, safe working conditions, and the means to increase awareness of potential dangers.  Rich Products Corporation - Waycross Facility's objective is to prevent unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could potentially expose Associates and others to serious hazards.  An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire ammonia refrigeration system.  Workplace and process safety are major concerns to management and Associates alike.  The prevention and mitigation of unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could expose Associates and the community to serious hazards is of primary concern.   

Rich Products Corporation - Waycross Facility has developed this program in accordance with OSHA Title 29 CFR 1910.119, and the USEPA Title 40 CFR Part 68.  The program is designed to inform all Associates of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates in the event of a release or spill (i.e., emergency response plan, management of change procedures, preventative maintenance program, associate training, etc.).  In addition, Rich Products Corporation has generated "Rich Products Corporation Standards for Safety Performance" which outlines the corporate policy for safety policies, safety procedures, and sample programs for implementation at each facility owned by Rich Products Corporation. 

Rich Products Corporation - Waycross Facility has not had an accidental release over the last five years.

Rich Products Corporati

on - Waycross Facility has an emergency response program written to comply with OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 (n), OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120, and USEPA 40 CFR 68.95.  These regulations establish the parameters to be included in the emergency response plan.
